Regulated Substance and Stationary Source

The Milner Milling Company facility in Barnesville, GA is in the business of milling grains into various flours to be used in baking food products.  Wheat, by its nature, can carry a variety of bacteria and spores on its surface.  This flora can produce undesirable or harmful qualities in finished products.  Controlled introduction of chlorine gas into the flour during milling reduces the flora to acceptable levels.  Further, chlorine produces reactions in the raw flour which can be advantageous in the baking process.

Pressurized chlorine is stored as liquid in one ton cylinders at the mill. Chlorine is introduced into the milling system via multiple tank connections to a common manifold sized to the demand rate required by the particular mill.  Chlorine is drawn through a Gas Pressure Reducing Valve and a Vacuum Regulator ? Pressure Check unit, and enters the chlorinators under vacuum rather than under pressure.  This greatly reduces the probability of a leak of chlorine from the chlorine delivery piping.  

The maximum intended inventory of chlorine at this site is 16,000 pounds, which exceeds the EPA?s threshold quantity of 2,500 pounds.  Milner Milling is therefore subject to RMP requirements under CAA 112 (r).

Offsite Hazard Assessment

EPA requirements under this rule include an assessment of the hazard and offsite consequences of a release of the regulated substance.  This must include analysis of two release scenarios (Worst Case and Alternate Case) in order to determine the toxic end point.

The model used to determine the distances to the toxic end point was EPA?s OCA Guidance Reference Tables.  Under the Worst Case scenario, a catastrophic failure of one chlorine cylinder, 2,000 pounds of chlorine would be released within 10 minutes.  A wind speed of 1.5 meters per second was assumed, yielding a model distance to toxic end point of 3.0 miles.  Based on data from the 2000 US Census, a residential population of 2

,400 is estimated within a 3.0 mile radius of the facility.

Under the Alternative Release scenario, 1,500 pounds of chlorine would leak from the storage vessel within 10 minutes.  A wind speed of 3.0 meters per second was assumed, yielding a 0.60 mile model distance to toxic endpoint.  Based on data from the 2000 US Census, a residential population of 70 is estimated within a 0.60 mile radius of the facility.

A topographic map in Appendix D shows the radius of exposure under both scenarios.

Prevention of Chlorine Release

The process is designed and maintained in compliance with recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices as shown in the Process Safety information that is incorporated within the Process Safety Management (PSM) document on file at the facility.  It is Milner Milling?s policy to adhere to all applicable Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends on the manner in which we operate and maintain the chlorine storage and dispensing system.  We have retained American Ingredients Company, a nationally recognized expert firm, to perform all periodic and preventive maintenance, and to provide frequent and thorough training to our personnel.  Safety and maintenance procedures outlined in the PSM are followed, and will minimize the potential of a release of chlorine to the environment.

Five Year Accident History

No accidental releases have occurred in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

Despite the Prevention Program noted above, incidents may still occur.  Milner Milling works with emergency responders, the Lamar County EPC, who are trained to respond to a release.
